questions.question: Ciliocytophthoria is seen in?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Acute respiratory infection Explanation: Ciliocytophthoria is a degenerative process of the ciliated cells , occurring in viral infections such as acute respiratory infections and characterized by typical morphological changes. The images below show the ciliary changes: Kartagener’s syndrome (Immotile cilia syndrome) (Option A) : It is a form of primary ciliary dyskinesia, characterized by a triad of: Sinusitis. Situs inversus (Option C) . Bronchiectasis. The ciliary ultrastructure is normal in cystic fibrosis (Option B) Reference: Ciliocytophthoria of nasal epithelial cells after viral infection: a sign of suffering cell - PMC

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding extralobular sequestration?

options.A: It is external to the lung.
options.B: It most commonly presents as a mass lesion.
options.C: It most often occurs in older children.
options.D: It has a separate pleural covering.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It most often occurs in older children. Explanation: The false statement regarding extra lobar sequestration is that it most often occurs in older children, most commonly in infants . Pulmonary sequestration is a discrete area of lung tissue not connected to the airways and has an abnormal blood supply from the aorta or its branches. It is of two types: Extralobar sequestration. Intralobar sequestration. Extralobar sequestration Intralobar sequestration Location External to the lung parenchyma (Option A) Within the lung parenchyma Pleural covering It has a separate pleural covering (Option D) Shares pleura with adjacent lung tissue Embryological origin Congenital anomaly of the primitive foregut Association It causes a mass effect (Option B) Localized infection or bronchiectasis Venous return The right side of the heart through IVC Pulmonary veins Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 674

questions.question: A 65-year-old female presents to the clinic with a productive cough, fever, and fatigue for the past two weeks. She has a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus and reports recent hospitalisation for a urinary tract infection. On physical examination, coarse crackles are auscultated over the right lower lung fields. The chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most common risk factor for developing this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Aspiration of infective material Explanation: Given the clinical presentation of productive cough, fever, fatigue, and the presence of a thick-walled cavity with surrounding consolidation on chest X-ray, the most likely diagnosis is a lung abscess. Lung abscess: It describes a local suppurative process that produces necrosis of the lung tissue. Aetiology: Bacteroides , Fusobacterium , and Peptostreptococcus (the three most common bacteria). Aerobic and anaerobic Streptococci, S. aureus, and gram-negative organisms. Risk factors: Aspiration of infective material (the most frequent cause) (Option B) . Septic embolism. (Option C) Morphology: Pulmonary abscesses due to aspiration are more common on the right (because of the more vertical right main bronchus ) and are most often single. The cardinal histologic change in all abscesses is the suppurative destruction of the lung parenchyma within the central area of cavitation. The image below shows a lung abscess

questions.question: A 29-year-old previously healthy male presents with a one-week history of progressively worsening dry cough, fever, and shortness of breath. He denies any recent travel but mentions attending a crowded social gathering a week ago. He is febrile, tachypneic, and has crackles on auscultation. Laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis with lymphopenia. A chest X-ray demonstrates patchy infiltrates in the lower lobes bilaterally. Which of the following features is not associated with this condition?

options.A: Inflammatory changes are confined to the pulmonary interstitium.
options.B: Neutrophils are involved in this infection.
options.C: It is associated with malnutrition and alcoholism.
options.D: It is also known as walking pneumonia.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Neutrophils are involved in this infection. Explanation: The clinical presentation of a patient with a history of attending a crowded social gathering, worsening dry cough, fever, shortness of breath, crackles on auscultation, and chest X-ray showing bilateral patchy infiltrates in the lower lobes is suggestive of Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection (Atypical pneumonia) . Neutrophils are not involved in this condition; rather, lymphocytes are involved. Neutrophils are involved in typical pneumonia. Atypical pneumonia: Definition An acute febrile respiratory disease characterised by patchy inflammatory changes in the lungs, largely confined to the alveolar septa and pulmonary interstitium. (Option A) Aetiology Atypical organisms: Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Most common). It is also known as walking pneumonia , as the patient is not bedridden. (Option D) Chlamydia pneumoniae. Coxiella burnetii (Q-fever). Viruses Morphology Interstitial inflammatory reaction , virtually localised within the walls of the alveoli. Alveolar septa are widened and edematous and usually have a mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate of lymphocytes , macrophages, and occasionally plasma cells. Herpes simplex , varicella , and adenovirus may be associated with bronchial and alveolar epithelium necrosis and acute inflammation. Typical pneumonia: Cause: Bacterial Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common). Haemophilus influenzae. Klebsiella pneumoniae. Neutrophils are involved in this condition. Features: Intra-alveolar exudate and productive cough.

questions.question: Red hepatisation of the lungs is seen on which day?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2-4 Explanation: Stages of bacterial pneumonia: Stage Days Characteristics Congestion 1-2 (Option A) Gross: The lung is heavy, boggy, and red. Microscopic: Vascular engorgement , intra-alveolar fluid with neutrophils & bacteria. Red hepatization 2-4 (Option B) Gross: Red , firm, and airless , with a liver-like consistency , hence the term hepatization. Microscopic: Confluent exudation with neutrophils, RBCs , and fibrin filling the alveoli. Grey hepatization 5-8 (Option C) Gross: Greyish brown and dry surface. Microscopic: Disintegration of RBCs and persistence of a fibrinosuppurative exudate. Resolution 8-9 (Option D) Exudates within the alveoli are broken down by enzymatic digestion to produce granular debris. Debris may be reabsorbed/ingested by macrophages/expectorated/ organised by fibroblasts. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 708

questions.question: A 55-year-old male with a long-standing history of chronic alcohol abuse presents with a one-week history of high-grade fever, productive cough with rust-coloured sputum, and right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He reports frequent binge drinking episodes and denies any recent travel or sick contacts. On examination, he appears ill, with a temperature of 39.5°C, tachypnea, and decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung fields. Laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis with neutrophilia and elevated inflammatory markers. What is the most likely organism implicated in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Klebsiella pneumoniae Explanation: The clinical presentation of a patient who is a known alcoholic , presenting with high-grade fever, productive cough, rust-coloured (red currant jelly) sputum, right-sided pleuritic chest pain, decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung fields, and neutrophilia is suggestive of pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae. Klebsiella pneumoniae: It is the most common cause of gram-negative bacterial pneumonia. It causes typical pneumonia with neutrophil-rich exudate that fills the bronchi, bronchioles, and adjacent alveolar spaces. It commonly afflicts debilitated and malnourished people , particularly chronic alcoholics. Thick, mucoid (often blood-tinged) sputum is characteristic because the organism produces an abundant viscid capsular polysaccharide , which the patient may have difficulty expectorating. Mycoplasma Pneumonia (Option A) Mycoplasma pneumonia causes atypical pneumonia with dry cough, fever, and fatigue. It often presents with mild symptoms but can lead to complications. It presents with a persistent dry cough, low-grade fever, sore throat, headache, and fatigue. Chest X-ray findings may appear worse than clinical symptoms. It spreads via respiratory droplets and is common in young adults and crowded settings. Treatment includes macrolides or tetracyclines. Legionella pneumophila (Option B): Legionella pneumophila is the agent of legionnaires’ disease and Pontiac fever , a self-limited upper respiratory tract infection. It flourishes in artificial aquatic environments, such as water-cooling towers and the tubing systems of domestic (potable) water supplies. It is common in individuals with predisposing conditions such as cardiac, renal, immunologic, or hematologic disease and organ transplant recipients . Moraxella catarrhalis (Option C): Moraxella catarrhalis is recognised as a cause of bacterial pneumonia, especially in the elderly . It is the second most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbation of COPD. Along with S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae, M. catarrhalis is one of the three most common causes of otitis media in children. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10 Edition Page 708

questions.question: Match the following: 1) Pneumocystis pneumonia a) 2) Blastomycosis b) 3) Aspergillus c) 4) Measles d)
Which of the following conditions is not associated with aspiration?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Nelson syndrome Explanation: Nelson syndrome is not associated with aspiration. It is a rare disorder that occurs in some individuals who have undergone surgical removal of both adrenal glands to treat Cushing's disease. It is characterised by the growth of a pituitary tumour, often resulting in elevated levels of ACTH and increased skin pigmentation. Aspiration pneumonia: It occurs in markedly debilitated patients or those who aspirate gastric contents either while unconscious (e.g., after a stroke) or during repeated vomiting. Predisposing factors: Abnormal gag and swallowing reflexes. The resultant pneumonia is partly chemical due to the irritating effects of gastric acid and partly bacterial (from the oral flora). More than one organism is recovered in culture (aerobes > anaerobes). It is often necrotising with a fulminant clinical course, and a frequent cause of death. In patients who survive, lung abscess is a common complication. Conditions associated with aspiration: Mendelson syndrome (Option A): It occurs due to aspiration of gastric contents during general anaesthesia. Risk factors: Pregnancy. Gastric volume >25 ml (0.4 mL/kg). Gastric pH <2.5 Meconium aspiration syndrome (Option C) : It usually occurs in term or post-term babies who are small for gestational age (IUGR). Lipoid pneumonia/Golden pneumonia (Option B): Associated with Oil aspiration- Mineral oil industry. Macrophages engulf the lipids. The image below shows the histology of lipoid pneumonia Reference: Robbins & Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page no. 711 Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no. 1352

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with a persistent cough, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. Chest X-ray reveals an infiltrate in the upper lobe of the right lung. Which of the following pathological processes is not seen in this condition? membrane of the phagosome.

options.A: Th2-mediated macrophage activation and killing of bacteria.
options.B: The bacterium blocks phagolysosome formation by recruiting a host protein called coronin to the
options.C: M. tuberculosis is recognised by innate immunity receptors.
options.D: It causes granulomatous inflammation and damage.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Th2-mediated macrophage activation and killing of bacteria. Explanation: The clinical presentation of a 45-year-old male with a persistent cough, night sweats, unintentional weight loss, and chest X-ray showing an infiltrate in the upper lobe of the right lung is suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis. Th2-mediated macrophage activation and bacteria killing is not seen in tuberculosis. Rather, a Th-1-mediated response is seen. Pathogenesis of tuberculosis: Infection by M. tuberculosis proceeds in steps, from initial infection of macrophages to a subsequent Th1 response that both contains the bacteria and causes tissue damage. Early in infection, M. tuberculosis replicates essentially unchecked within macrophages, and later in infection, the cell response stimulates macrophages to contain the proliferation of the bacteria. The steps for infection are as follows: Entry into macrophages M. tuberculosis enters macrophages by phagocytosis . Replication in macrophages M. tuberculosis inhibits the maturation of the phagosome. It blocks the formation of the phagolysosome (Option B) , allowing the bacterium to replicate unchecked within the vesicle. Thus, during the earliest stage of primary tuberculosis (<3 weeks) in the nonsensitized individual, bacteria proliferate in the pulmonary alveolar macrophages and air spaces, resulting in bacteremia and seeding of multiple sites. Despite the bacteremia, most people at this stage are asymptomatic or have a mild flu-like illness. Innate immunity (Option C) Mycobacterial lipoarabinomannan binds TLR2 , and unmethylated CpG nucleotides bind TLR9. These interactions initiate and enhance the innate and adaptive immune responses to M. tuberculosis, as described below. Th1 response , Th1 mediated macrophage activation, and killing of the bacteria (mediated by IFN- γ ). Granulomatous inflammation and damage (mediated by Th1 response ) (Option D) . Caseous necrosis and giant cell formation (epithelioid histiocytes-giant cells, mediated by IFN- γ ). Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease,10th Edition, Page 378

questions.question: Match the following lesions with their site of occurrence. Lesion Site 1 Puhl’s focus i Lung + Lymph node 2 Simon focus ii Blood vessels 3 Ghon complex iii Supraclavicular region of the lung 4 Weighert focus iv The apex of the lung
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-iii, 2-iv, 3-i, 4-ii Explanation: Puhl’s focus Supraclavicular region of the lung Simon focus Apex of the lung Ghon complex Lung + Lymph node Weighert focus Blood vessel Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection caused by M. tuberculosis. It is of the following types. Primary tuberculosis It develops in a previously unexposed and therefore unsensitized person. The primary organ involved is mostly the lungs . Location: Sub-pleural region. Lower part of the upper lobe & upper part of the lower lobe. Ghon’s focus: Grey-white area of inflammation with consolidation. Ghon’s complex: Ghon’s focus + inflamed regional lymph nodes (Statment iii) . Histology: Granulomatous inflammatory reaction with both caseating and non-caseating tubercles. Simon’s focus: Occult hematogenous dissemination to the apex of the lung. (Statement ii) Fate: 95% of the cases are controlled by immunity, calcified, healed lesions and hilar lymph nodes ( Ranke complex ). 5% of the cases are progressive (Progressive primary TB). Resembles acute bacterial pneumonia. Lymphohematogenous dissemination may cause tuberculous meningitis and/or miliary TB. Secondary tuberculosis It arises in a previously sensitised host. It may follow shortly after primary tuberculosis, but more commonly, it appears months to years after the initial infection, usually when the host resistance is weakened. The apical and posterior lobe segments are involved due to high O 2 concentration ( Puhl’s focus ) (Statement i) . The infraclavicular lesion is called Assman’s focus. Regional lymph node involvement is late. Cavitation occurs readily with the erosion of the cavities into an airway. Histology: Active lesions show coalescent tubercles with central caseation (Caseous necrosis). Disseminated TB: Spread to other organs. The images below show the caseous necrosis seen in TB. Other foci: Simmond focus: Liver. Weighert focus: Blood vessels (Statement iv) Rich’s focus: Brain.
